abstract.p: Article on home in Eastchester, NY, owned by Robert and Jean Ballasedis that location scout Kellie Morrison chose to rent, for $40,000, for filming of movie The Namesake, directed by Mira Nair; photo (M)

KELLIE MORRISON knocks on doors for a living. As a location scout, she is responsible for finding places suitable for filming. And because it gets more expensive to film the farther you get from Manhattan -- thanks to travel time and union costs -- her best tool is a map.

Twenty minutes north on the Hutchinson River Parkway, Ms. Morrison knocked on the door of a striking 4,000-square-foot, 45-year-old house in Eastchester in March 2005. The homeowners, Robert Ballasedis, 44, a salesman, and his wife, Jean, 42, not only answered, but also agreed to rent their house for ''The Namesake,'' a feature film directed by Mira Nair that opened March 9.
Their decision to rent their house for 53 days earned them $40,000 -- far less than it would have cost the movie's makers to build a set.

The movie is based on the popular novel of the same name by Jhumpa Lahiri, about a Bengali family that moves from Calcutta to the United States. The novel was set outside Boston, while the movie takes place in Queens and Westchester.
''I was kind of excited,'' said Mrs. Ballasedis, the mother of Robert, 5, and Christine, 4. ''No one really ever sees the back end of it, how a movie actually gets made.''

Two weeks after Ms. Morrison's visit, the many changes needed to turn the home into a film set began. It took three weeks, five days just to make the kitchen look 30 years old, the film's period. The hand-painted stencils in the kitchen were covered with bricklike wallpaper, and the cabinets were painted bright cobalt blue or covered in wood-grained contact paper. A metal dish rack that hung from the ceiling -- typical in Indian homes, said the film's production designer, Stephanie Carroll -- was ordered from India.
''I used the whole house as if I'd built it,'' Ms. Carroll said. ''We changed everything.''

The family's belongings, from the refrigerator to Mrs. Ballasedis's treasured collection of porcelain and crystal, were put in storage while the family took a three-week vacation. The living room (now beige again) was painted a brilliant scarlet and the hallway gray. Only an Air France coffee cup, which made it into the film, stayed behind.

''The main thing is that it fits the kind of house the characters would have lived in at the time,'' Ms. Carroll said. ''We wanted a cul de sac. We needed a large house with enough room for the crew, and I needed the lines of home to be really clean. Bengalis are very minimal in their tastes. They're very intellectual.''

Westchester won out for another reason -- the recently expanded Empire State Film Production Credit program, which is available to filmmakers whose budgets are more than $3 million and who use sets in New York or those who film 75 percent of their production in the state.
''A year earlier, we might well have looked at New Jersey,'' said the film's producer, Lydia Pilcher. ''We did scout different areas.''

The credit lowered the film's production costs by $600,000, a significant saving on their $10 million budget, she said. Westchester, which has been the setting of many films over the years -- like ''Big,'' ''A Beautiful Mind'' and ''The Good Shepherd'' -- is ''a great place to go to get the necessary scale,'' Ms. Pilcher said. ''If you need a small-town feel, many towns in Westchester give you that intimacy.''
